Not so Black and White: Uncovering Racial Bias from Systematically Misrecorded Trooper Reports

Law enforcement officers may purposely misrecord the race of citizens that they interact with in order to evade detection of racial bias. Using a unique event in Texas where Texas troopers were caught intentionally misrecording minority motorists as white, I propose a new test of racial bias in the presence of misrecording that is well-suited to explore the rich heterogeneity in bias behavior. By measuring the different misrecording rates across search outcome, I find bias against all minority motorists, but the most against Hispanic motorists. I disaggregate the bias to the individual trooper level and find that nearly 60\% of troopers were engaging in this behavior. Using my trooper-level measure of bias, I can identify causal relationships between bias and labor outcomes using a panel data of trooper employment outcomes and comparing employment outcomes to bias after the misrecording was revealed by the media in 2015. I find that this rule change was effective in curbing lying behavior in troopers and in reducing bias against Hispanic motorists.

Racial Bias in Parking Tickets and the Long Term effects of Bias

Biased application of parking laws may have greater detrimental effects on neighborhoods than previously estimated. Using an exogeneous increase in the fine for vehicle registration in Chicago enacted in 2017, I am able to test and measure racial bias in parking enforcement. I find that the increase in fines in black neighborhoods led to a 5% increase in driver’s license suspension, a 1% increase in bankruptcy declarations, and 10% increase in policing compared to white neighborhoods before and after the fine increase.
